f6f59cdf-a838-4c26-8972-d450dfa5b559.description: The Lincoln Award is the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support students to develop and learn how to demonstrate employability skills. As well as taking part in a variety of activities to develop skills and knowledge, students are supported to reflect on their experiences and prepare for the graduate labour market. To conclude students put their learning to the test in one of our employer-partnered Assessment Centres.
f6f59cdf-a838-4c26-8972-d450dfa5b559.name: The Lincoln Award

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a skills assessment based on the graduate labour market and use the results to inform activity choices and produce an action plan.
Complete 40 hours of paid work, volunteering or work experience.
Attend various industry or skills focused workshops, events or training, to develop experiences and competencies.

Participate in various activities to prepare for recruitment. Complete an online CV review, reflect on experiences and skills developed and learn how to communicate skills. Attend an interactive session to prepare for the Assessment Centre Experience.

Pass a Lincoln Award Assessment Centre to complete the award. Each Assessment Centre is partnered with an employer and based on a real job role. Students undertake a short interview, a written exercise and a group task and receive a feedback summary sheet after the event detailing their score, strengths and development areas for all activities. Students must meet the pass mark to complete the award.

1302ff29-717c-4de9-99de-7bd8d4b24a6c.description: The Lincoln Award Teaching scheme is coordinated by Careers & Employability in partnership with local teaching providers. The scheme is a pathway through the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support students to develop and learn how to demonstrate employability skills. As well as completing an internship in a school, students are introduced to a variety of activities to develop their skills and supported to reflect on their experiences to prepare for their future.
1302ff29-717c-4de9-99de-7bd8d4b24a6c.name: The Lincoln Award- Teaching pathway

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a skills assessment based on the graduate labour market and use the results to inform activity choices and produce an action plan.
Attend relevant preparation training for entering a teaching environment.
Complete an internship in a local school, working closely with a mentor.
Attend various industry and skills focused workshops, events and training delivered by careers staff, employers or external facilitators.
Participate in a group reflection session to reflect on experiences and the skills developed.
Complete a group presentation assessment to meet the pass criteria to achieve the award.

fb846824-ce00-42f3-8567-7e609b692e89.description: The Lincoln Award is the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support, enhance, and recognise extracurricular activity. As well as taking part in a variety of activities to develop skills, students are supported to reflect on their experiences and prepare to put their learning to the test in one of our employer-partnered Assessment Centres. The Lincoln Award Global is a bespoke pathway which focusses on global skills, global mind-set and intercultural communication.
fb846824-ce00-42f3-8567-7e609b692e89.name: The Lincoln Award Global

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a skills assessment based on the graduate labour market and use the results to inform activity choices and produce an action plan.
Complete 40 hours of paid work, volunteering or work experience.  Students must consider intercultural skills gained from this activity, and how these relate to working globally.
Attend various global themed workshops, events or training, to develop experiences and competencies.

Participate in various activities to prepare for recruitment. Complete an online CV review, reflect on experiences and skills developed and learn how to communicate skills. Attend an interactive session to prepare for the final activity, the Assessment Centre Experience, focussing on the identification and communication of skills in global recruitment processes,

Pass the Lincoln Award Global Assessment Centre to complete the award. Each Assessment Centre is partnered with a global employer and based on a real job role, with a focus on working globally. Students undertake a short interview, a written exercise, and a group task. Students receive a feedback summary sheet after the event detailing their score, strengths, and development areas for all activities. Students must meet the pass mark to complete the award.

7838f7f6-4af1-4f79-bddc-bf73196052bf.description: The Lincoln Award is the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support students to develop and learn how to demonstrate employability skills. Based on student feedback and employer insight, this pathway supports students to take their learning to the next level, maximising preparation for the labour market and the workplace. Students develop experience and skills to utilise throughout their career and vital tools to enable reflection, development, and lifelong learning.
7838f7f6-4af1-4f79-bddc-bf73196052bf.name: The Lincoln Award Plus

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a Strengths profile and undertake reflection and discussion for career planning.
Develop commercial awareness through experiential learning.  Undertake a course of combined online learning and project work before receiving feedback from an industry mentor.
Develop digital skills by undertaking 5 hours of online learning on a relevant topic. This is followed by reflection.
Attend a series of 7 training sessions focussing on life skills for early career and life long learning.

Deliver a 10 minute presentation on learning throughout the programme and engage in a reflective discussion.  Students receive a feedback summary sheet after the event detailing their score, strengths, and development areas.  Students must meet the pass mark to complete the award.

111c20a8-c6ca-436d-bd64-bfdc04da8669.description: The Lincoln Award is the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support, enhance, and recognise extracurricular activity. As well as taking part in a variety of activities to develop skills, students are supported to reflect on their experiences and prepare to put their learning to the test in one of our employer-partnered Assessment Centres. The Lincoln Award Geography is a bespoke pathway which focusses on related industry activities.
111c20a8-c6ca-436d-bd64-bfdc04da8669.name: The Lincoln Award- Geography pathway

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a skills assessment based on the graduate labour market and use the results to inform activity choices and produce an action plan.
Complete 40 hours of paid work, volunteering or work experience with relevant employers, volunteer organisations and geographical bodies.
Attend various industry and skills focused workshops, events or training, to develop experiences and competencies.

Participate in various activities to prepare for recruitment. Complete an online CV review, reflect on experiences and skills developed and learn how to communicate skills. Attend an interactive session to prepare for the Assessment Centre Experience.

Pass a Lincoln Award Assessment Centre to complete the award. The Assessment Centre is partnered with a industry related employer and based on a real job role. Students undertake a short interview, a written exercise and a group task and receive a feedback summary sheet after the event detailing their score, strengths and development areas for all activities. Students must meet the pass mark to complete the award.

c7708734-fbb0-4ff4-b221-14337d81ee7f.description: The Lincoln Award is the University of Lincoln's employability framework, designed to support students to develop and learn how to demonstrate employability skills. This STEM Ambassador pathway allows students to gain experience as a STEM Ambassador within a local school as well as gaining industry insight from senior STEM Ambassadors. Students are supported to reflect on their experiences and put their skills to the test in an employer-partnered assessment centre.
c7708734-fbb0-4ff4-b221-14337d81ee7f.name: The Lincoln Award- STEM Ambassador pathway

badge_template_activities.title: Complete a skills assessment based on the graduate labour market and use the results to inform activity choices and produce an action plan.
Gain 40 hours of experience in a local school, delivering to pupils and preparing resources.
Attend various industry or skills focused workshops, events or training, to develop experiences and competencies. Gaining insight from Senior STEM Ambassadors.

Participate in various activities to prepare for recruitment. Complete an online CV review, reflect on experiences and skills developed and learn how to communicate skills. Attend an interactive session to prepare for the Assessment Centre Experience.

Pass a Lincoln Award Assessment Centre to complete the award. Each Assessment Centre is partnered with an employer and based on a real job role. Students undertake a short interview, a written exercise and a group task and receive a feedback summary sheet after the event detailing their score, strengths and development areas for all activities. Students must meet the pass mark to complete the award.

079c7fcc-80ac-4ce3-bcdd-e287deb43773.description: The 'Managing self and others' course is designed to develop knowledge and skills about leadership and management by exploring and critically reflecting on concepts, approaches and behaviours associated with leadership. Microcredential courses are designed are to help strengthen professional credentials in a range of specialised areas. These accessible short courses cover key practical and theoretical in-demand skills.
079c7fcc-80ac-4ce3-bcdd-e287deb43773.name: Managing self and others.

badge_template_activities.title: Successfully completed the 'Managing self and others' microcredential course.
Successfully passed formal assessment worth 5-credits at Master’s level.
Demonstrated, through reflection, an enhanced capacity to manage personal learning and development.
Critically analysed theoretical models of leadership and management in relation to personal and organisational leadership practice.
Identified and critiqued the elements of individual, group and organisational behaviour which underpin leadership and management practice.
